content.description:
Shark Bit has fun climbing up a loose and dirty dihedral. From the P2 anchor of

Bottom Feeder

, step 6 feet left, and climb up on positive holds to a good 0.4 or #1 cam. Continue up stemming to avoid loose rock, and step left up high to avoid loose chockstones. Continue up to a white plaque of rock with a crack, and clip a final bolt to protect the finish as you exit right onto the ledge.
content.protection: A single rack should suffice and one bolt.
content.location:
Start 6 feet left of the P2 anchor of

Bottom Feeder

.

content.description:
From the pitch 1 anchor of

Acidification

, trend out right and exit the lower roof on the right side then up to join pitch 3 of

Acidification

.
content.location:
This is a second pitch variation to the route

Acidification

!

climbs.name: Bottom Feeder
climbs.fa: P1 Todd Reeves; Andrew Aldercotte, July, 27 2019. P2 Todd Reeves; Amos Whiting, Aug. 20, 2019; P3 Todd Reeves, Andrew Aldercotte, Aug. 31, 2019

content.description:
P1. 5.6. Follow a right-trending series of 6 bolts to a dirty ledge with loose rock. The anchor bolts are obvious up and left. If you are continuing to the 5.7 pitch

Cleaning the Coral

, clip a traversing bolt to protect the follower on the ledge.

P2. 5.10b. Continue above the anchor through 5 bolts. Traverse under the roof, and clip a bolt before committing to the crack above with gear placements. A final bolt protects the crux. Trend up and left to a bolted anchor. Please respect any loose rock on the ledge.

P3. 5.9 PG13. From the P2 anchor, climb left on a bouldery hand traverse and clip a bolt overhead. Move right and up on 3 bolts to finger size gear. Clip a bolt through the crux and finish up and right at the rappel anchor. You are now below the magnificent Wave formation...pick your pleasure. Alternately, you can traverse right from the P2 anchors on the ledge to a rap anchor or continue past a tree to the third pitch 5.8 of

Acidification

.
content.protection: Mixed climbing, mostly bolts. At the headwall crux, a medium piece like a #2 or #3 BD will protect the crack.
content.location:
Bottom Feeder begins 40 feet to the left of

Acidification

. See the photo.

climbs.name: Acidification
climbs.fa: Todd Reeves; Sammy Podhurst; Andrew Aldercotte, Sept. 2018

content.description:
Acidification is a 3-pitch outing that climbs through the lower tier of rock called The Coral.

P1. 5.10a. Climb the black water streak through 3 bolts to a hand crack in a roof (#1 or #2 Camalot), then finish with an optional #0.75 Camalot before the ledge and bolted anchor. The opening moves are the crux.

P2. 5.9. Continue above the anchor on a slab, and mantel onto a bushy ledge. Investigate the crack above, and exit right under the large roof to ledge and bolted anchor.

P3. 5.8. Relocate the belay just left of a large, dead, standing tree. Climb up through a mini-roof, and follow cracks as they trend up and right. You are now standing on a large ledge system with evergreen trees below the feature called The Wave.

NOTE: a variation to pitch 2 angles right from the anchor and is called Cleaning the Coral at 5.7.
content.protection: P1: 3 bolts, a #1 or #2 Cam, and a #0.75 for the finish. P2 & P3 a single rack with nuts should suffice.
content.location:
Follow approach beta and photo info for the Wild Ridge area. This is approximately 80 yards to the right of the

El Diablo de Oro

start. In The Coral Zone, locate a black water streak and the 1st bolt.
